docs.snippet: Northwest Airlines will begin offering nonstop flights to Beijing from Detroit on May 1, becoming the first United States carrier to provide such service, the company said today. Minneapolis-based Northwest will begin service  with three flights a we
docs.lead_paragraph: Northwest Airlines will begin offering nonstop flights to Beijing from Detroit on May 1, becoming the first United States carrier to provide such service, the company said today. Minneapolis-based Northwest will begin service with three flights a week in each direction. Northwest can increase that service to nine flights by 1998 under a United States-China agreement.

docs.abstract: Bao Tong, highest-ranking Chinese Communist Party official jailed for actions during 1989 pro-democracy demonstration in Tiananmen Square, remains in isolated detention in hills near Beijing three months after release from prison; challenged Prime Min Li Peng and other hard-liners who advocated martial law to clear Square of thousands of protestors encamped there after crisis erupted (M)

headline.main: Chinese Aide, Released From Prison, Is Still Held in Isolation

docs.snippet: Bao Tong's family says he would like to learn to play classical music on the piano and, at the age of 63, receive a thorough medical examination before getting on with his life after seven years in prison.    But three months after the release of Mr.
docs.lead_paragraph: Bao Tong's family says he would like to learn to play classical music on the piano and, at the age of 63, receive a thorough medical examination before getting on with his life after seven years in prison. But three months after the release of Mr. Bao, the highest-ranking Communist Party official jailed for his actions during the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations at Tiananmen Square, he remains in isolated detention in the hills west of Beijing.

docs.abstract: Frugal Traveler article on visiting Beijing, and finding her way through maze of streets and alleyways; photos; map (S)
docs.snippet: BEFORE I arrived in Beijing, I thought I was invincible. Like a bird dog in the woods, I could find my way around any city, as long as I had a map. I couldn't even remember what it felt like to be lost. But it all came rushing back to me when I got o
docs.lead_paragraph: BEFORE I arrived in Beijing, I thought I was invincible. Like a bird dog in the woods, I could find my way around any city, as long as I had a map. I couldn't even remember what it felt like to be lost. But it all came rushing back to me when I got off a rattletrap airport bus on Jianguomennei Avenue in central Beijing one morning in early October. The 22-hour flight from New York (on Air China for $1,000 round trip) had left me groggy, of course, and the smog was unusually thick, even for Beijing, where many residents cook and heat with coal. Still, I felt sure that if I just walked a few blocks northwest I'd end up on Wangfujing Street, Beijing's main shopping artery, which would eventually lead me to the little Lu Song Yuan Hotel, where I'd booked a room by fax for 298 yuan, about $36, a night (calculating the yuan at 8.3 to the dollar).

docs.abstract: Correction of Frugal Traveler article Nov 24 on Beijing
docs.snippet: The Frugal Traveler column on Nov. 24, about Beijing, misstated the number of rooms in the Forbidden City. It is 9,000, not 900.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Frugal Traveler column on Nov. 24, about Beijing, misstated the number of rooms in the Forbidden City. It is 9,000, not 900.
